articles.headline: Furor on Rush to Require Cervical Cancer Vaccine
articles.snippet: At about $400 the vaccine is costly, and many say the rush toward mandatory inoculation could prove counterproductive.
articles.abstract: At about $400 the vaccine is costly, and many say the rush toward mandatory inoculation could prove counterproductive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Racing to embrace a new vaccine, at least 20 states are considering mandatory inoculation of young girls against the sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Saul and Andrew Pollack

articles.headline: Long Delays Hurt Image of JetBlue
articles.snippet: Can one very bad week for JetBlue Airways wipe out years of industry-leading customer satisfaction ratings?
articles.abstract: Can one very bad week for JetBlue Airways wipe out years of industry-leading customer satisfaction ratings?
articles.lead_paragraph: Can one very bad week for JetBlue Airways wipe out years of industry-leading customer satisfaction ratings?

articles.headline: Rising Price of Electricity Sets Off New Debate on Regulation
articles.snippet: Opening up electricity markets to competition lead to soaring prices and the power industry is warning of a looming crisis.
articles.abstract: Opening up electricity markets to competition lead to soaring prices and the power industry is warning of a looming crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARION, Ill., Feb. 12 — Robert Butler has seen and heard a lot in his 44 years as mayor of this small southern Illinois town. But not even the blizzard of 1987 compares with the distress many residents expressed after they opened electricity bills for January that were double or even triple December’s.

articles.headline: Of Taxes, Newspapers and Family
articles.snippet: When the Chandler family sold Times-Mirror to Tribune in 2000, for $8 billion, the Tribune Company inherited two contentious partnerships.
articles.abstract: When the Chandler family sold Times-Mirror to Tribune in 2000, for $8 billion, the Tribune Company inherited two contentious partnerships.
articles.lead_paragraph: A little more than a year ago, representatives of the Chandler family approached the management of the Tribune Company, hoping to solve a little tax problem. Years before, when the family still owned Times-Mirror, it had set up two partnerships with the company that allowed the family to diversify its holdings without having to actually sell any Times-Mirror stock — thus avoiding a big tax bill. When the family sold Times-Mirror to Tribune in 2000, for $8 billion, a price that now seems be rich beyond belief, the Tribune Company inherited the partnerships.

articles.headline: Growth Drug Is Caught Up in Patent Fight
articles.snippet: A corporate dispute could take away a treatment that allows for fewer injections.
articles.abstract: A corporate dispute could take away a treatment that allows for fewer injections.

articles.headline: Iranian Force, Focus of U.S., Still a Mystery
articles.snippet: The Quds Force is under intense scrutiny by U.S. intelligence agencies because it is suspected of supplying explosives to Iraqi militants.
articles.abstract: The Quds Force is under intense scrutiny by U.S. intelligence agencies because it is suspected of supplying explosives to Iraqi militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 — Like so much else about the Iranian state, the Quds Force, which conducts overseas operations for Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, remains remarkably mysterious even to those who closely study the country.

articles.headline: Italy Indicts C.I.A. Operatives in ’03 Abduction
articles.snippet: The indictment of 26 Americans marked a turning point in Europe, where anger is high at the United States’ program of “extraordinary renditions.”
articles.abstract: The indictment of 26 Americans marked a turning point in Europe, where anger is high at the United States’ program of “extraordinary renditions.”
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME, Feb. 16 —An Italian judge indicted 26 Americans on Friday, most of them C.I.A. officers, in what will become the first trial of the American program of secretly whisking away terror suspects. Italy’s former top spy was also indicted.

articles.headline: Old McDonald Gave a Tour of His Farm
articles.snippet: Some small farms, faced with stagnant income and mounting expenses, are opening up their operations to nonagricultural activities just to survive.
articles.abstract: Some small farms, faced with stagnant income and mounting expenses, are opening up their operations to nonagricultural activities just to survive.
articles.lead_paragraph: PESCADERO, Calif. — It was no ordinary business outing for Erik Franks. Under a steely sky one recent Saturday morning, Mr. Franks and some colleagues from a nearby law firm visited Harley Farms, a nine-acre dairy farm here, for a tour and a crash course in the art of making goat cheese.

articles.headline: Planning Seen in Iraqi Attacks on U.S. Copters
articles.snippet: Documents captured from insurgents indicate that some of the recent attacks are the result of a strategy to down coalition aircraft.
articles.abstract: Documents captured from insurgents indicate that some of the recent attacks are the result of a strategy to down coalition aircraft.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 — Documents captured from Iraqi insurgents indicate that some of the recent fatal attacks against American helicopters are a result of a carefully planned strategy to focus on downing coalition aircraft, one that American officials say has been carried out by mounting coordinated assaults with machine guns, rockets and surface-to-air missiles.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and David S. Cloud

articles.headline: Will Other Mortgage Dominoes Fall?
articles.snippet: It’s amazing how long it can take investors to see that the wheels are coming off a prized investment vehicle. Denial, after all, is a powerful thing.
articles.abstract: It’s amazing how long it can take investors to see that the wheels are coming off a prized investment vehicle. Denial, after all, is a powerful thing.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT’S amazing how long it can take investors to see that the wheels are coming off a prized investment vehicle. Denial, after all, is a powerful thing.

articles.headline: A Media Mogul Tries Remote Control
articles.snippet: Robert L. Johnson’s calendar has become very crowded, thanks to a high-powered push to start and buy several companies.
articles.abstract: Robert L. Johnson’s calendar has become very crowded, thanks to a high-powered push to start and buy several companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Charlotte, N.C.

articles.headline: A Film Star in Kampala, Conjuring Amin’s Ghost
articles.snippet: “The Last King of Scotland” depicts an era Ugandans like to forget, but they are proud it is about their country.
articles.abstract: “The Last King of Scotland” depicts an era Ugandans like to forget, but they are proud it is about their country.
articles.lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda, Feb. 17 — This year, the Oscar buzz has made it all the way to Kampala.

articles.headline: Jailed 2 Years, Iraqi Tells of Abuse by Americans
articles.snippet: A former detainee said U.S. guards casually used stun guns and exposed prisoners to periods of heat and cold.
articles.abstract: A former detainee said U.S. guards casually used stun guns and exposed prisoners to periods of heat and cold.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — In the early hours of Jan. 6, Laith al-Ani stood in a jail near the Baghdad airport waiting to be released by the American military after two years and three months in captivity.
articles.byline: By Michael Moss and Souad Mekhennet

articles.headline: How to Work More Hours and Still Go Home Early
articles.snippet: As older baby boomers leave the work force and younger workers move into senior management, the workday is becoming much less rigidly defined.
articles.abstract: As older baby boomers leave the work force and younger workers move into senior management, the workday is becoming much less rigidly defined.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN we think of someone putting in long hours on the job, the image is often one of late nights and the proverbial midnight oil. But professionals like Andrew Grumet, 34, a tax lawyer at Herrick, Feinstein, would rather clock many of those hours early in the morning.

articles.headline: Debtors Search for Discipline via Blogs
articles.snippet: Some people say describing their fiscal intimacies online helps push them to pay their debt off.
articles.abstract: Some people say describing their fiscal intimacies online helps push them to pay their debt off.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a woman who calls herself Tricia discovered last week that she owed $22,302 on her credit cards, she could not wait to spread the news. Tricia, 29, does not talk to her family or friends about her finances, and says she is ashamed of her personal debt.

articles.headline: For Yale’s Money Man, a Higher Calling
articles.snippet: In the competitive, performance-driven world of money managers, David F. Swensen can boast of an extraordinary record.
articles.abstract: In the competitive, performance-driven world of money managers, David F. Swensen can boast of an extraordinary record.
articles.lead_paragraph: New Haven

articles.headline: JetBlue’s C.E.O. Is ‘Mortified’ After Fliers Are Stranded
articles.snippet: Hoping to win forgiveness from customers, the airline’s founder promised an overhaul after a huge breakdown in operations.
articles.abstract: Hoping to win forgiveness from customers, the airline’s founder promised an overhaul after a huge breakdown in operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The founder and chief executive of JetBlue Airways, his voice cracking at times, called himself “humiliated and mortified” by a huge breakdown in the airline’s operations that has dragged on for nearly a week, and promised that in the future JetBlue would pay penalties to customers if they were stranded on a plane for too long.

articles.headline: Terror Officials See Al Qaeda Chiefs Regaining Power
articles.snippet: American officials say Al Qaeda has re-established significant control over its once battered worldwide terror network.
articles.abstract: American officials say Al Qaeda has re-established significant control over its once battered worldwide terror network.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 — Senior leaders of Al Qaeda operating from Pakistan have re-established significant control over their once-battered worldwide terror network and over the past year have set up a band of training camps in the tribal regions near the Afghan border, according to American intelligence and counterterrorism officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and David Rohde

articles.headline: New Weapon in Web War Over Piracy
articles.snippet: Content-recognition software could address a major entertainment industry concern— songs and videos being posted on the Web without permission.
articles.abstract: Content-recognition software could address a major entertainment industry concern— songs and videos being posted on the Web without permission.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 — As media companies struggle to reclaim control over their movies, television shows and music in a world of online file-sharing software, they have found an ally in software of another kind.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: Do They Still Want Their MTV?
articles.snippet: MTV has managed to reinvent itself continuously, but finding the edge was simpler before competition for its core demographic started coming from all fronts.
articles.abstract: MTV has managed to reinvent itself continuously, but finding the edge was simpler before competition for its core demographic started coming from all fronts.
articles.lead_paragraph: MTV prospered for decades because it looked like what a network might look like if a 16-year-old were doing the programming. But now the music channel is trying to make its way in a multidevice, multiplatform, multichannel world, most of which is being programmed by a 16-year-old.

articles.headline: Iraqi Sunni Lands Show New Oil and Gas Promise
articles.snippet: New estimates of the amount of oil and natural gas on Sunni lands are likely to have significant political effects.
articles.abstract: New estimates of the amount of oil and natural gas on Sunni lands are likely to have significant political effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: KARABILA, Iraq, Feb. 18 — In a remote patch of the Anbar desert just 20 miles from the Syrian border, a single blue pillar of flanges and valves sits atop an enormous deposit of oil and natural gas that would be routine in this petroleum-rich country except for one fact: this is Sunni territory.

articles.headline: Music Labels Offer Teasers to Download
articles.snippet: The expansion of the online marketplace is now all but forcing the music companies to tread on ground they once viewed as off limits.
articles.abstract: The expansion of the online marketplace is now all but forcing the music companies to tread on ground they once viewed as off limits.
articles.lead_paragraph: For all the disquiet the Internet has fostered in the music business, almost every rock star and record executive is intrigued with the prospect of marketing to music fans directly instead of wrangling for exposure with radio programmers or retailers.

articles.headline: As Clinton Runs, Some Old Foes Stay on Sideline
articles.snippet: Many conservatives say that the intensity of anger toward Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has subsided.
articles.abstract: Many conservatives say that the intensity of anger toward Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has subsided.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 — Back when Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was first lady, no one better embodied what she once called the “vast right-wing conspiracy” than Richard Mellon Scaife.

articles.headline: Old Media Partying With Oscar Online
articles.snippet: Magazines and other publications have built Oscar Web sites in hopes of cementing the loyalty of Web surfers.
articles.abstract: Magazines and other publications have built Oscar Web sites in hopes of cementing the loyalty of Web surfers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here are two numbers to think about next Sunday night when you are rolling your eyes at the length of time it takes an Oscar winner to say thank you.

articles.headline: For New Line, an Identity Crisis
articles.snippet: Still riding on residual profits from the “Lord of the Rings” trilogy, New Line Cinema is going back to the basics.
articles.abstract: Still riding on residual profits from the “Lord of the Rings” trilogy, New Line Cinema is going back to the basics.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18 — For six weeks in 2005, Robert K. Shaye, the founder and co-chairman of New Line Cinema, lay in a coma in a New York City hospital, fending off death from a sudden infection.
